page.title: 04CLITHEROE'S OLD QUARRY
page.content: In 1307 where Salthill Quarry is today there was woodland. On the 8th of June 1307 the Earl of Lincoln, who was also the Lord Honor of Clitheroe, decided to make this woodland into a quarry. The quarrying of limestone for walling and for lime was taking place as early as 1651. This is known because a "Court of Inquiry" for that year made out an order fining people if they extracted limestone without a licence. To extract the limestone at Salthill the rock face needed to be blasted using high explosives. For many years 'black powder' was used as the explosive. The explosions when blasting in the quarry could be felt all over Clitheroe and as far away as Low Moor.
